What to Know When Buying Essential Oils_ Myth vs Reality

Posted 21, April 2018 by
Dr. Dayana Deschamps - 0 min read

Herbs and plants have been used for thousands of years to help relieve ailments, their causes, and symptoms. The history of essential oils goes back as far as thousands of years ago. A 20,000-year-old cave paintings of Palaeolithic people in Lascaux, France suggest the use of medicinal plants in everyday life.

Many biblical figures used essential oils for healing purposes and as cleansing agents. Public records and studies show that Egyptians used essential oils, balsams, and perfumed oils; as well as scented barks, resins, spices, and aromatic vinegar daily. They even had a god called Nefertum; the god of perfume who was also the god of healing. The oils had all kinds of use such as purification of the soul, celebration of the gods, and mummification passage to the “after-life”; as well as house cleaning, and even to protect their skin under the sun.

The beginning of aromatherapy and the use of essential oils in modern time

Essential oils are used by many different cultures all over the world. It was the French chemist and perfumer Rene Maurice Gattefosse who coined the term aromatherapy; as we know it today in 1937. A non-believer of the natural health movement; however, he became interested in essential oils after badly burning his hand during an experiment. He then plunged them into the nearest bath of liquid which just happened to be a lavender essential oil.
Later, he was astonished to see that the burn healed very quickly and left practically no scarring. His fascination with essential oils inspired him to experiment with them during the First World War on soldiers in military hospitals. He used oils of lavender, thyme, lemon and clove for their antiseptic properties.

How is essential oil made?

Oils are extracted in different ways. Most extraction techniques are based on the fact that the majority of essential oils mix well with oils; as well as fats, alcohol, and certain solvents but not with water. Most pure essential oils are extracted from plants through steam distillation.
The plants are freshly picked then suspended over boiling water. The steam pulls the oils out of the plants, as the steam rises it is captured in a container and pushed through a tube. The steam is then cooled down and condensed back to the water. Since water and essential oils do not mix, the two separate and the oil is collected. They are also called Volatile Oils because they are very easily vaporized.

How to use them for maximum absorption?

  • Via the skin

The skin is our largest organ, making it easier for many nutrients or toxins to get absorbed faster. Our bodies absorb directly into the bloodstream close to 60% of the topical products applied to the skin; massaging  with essential oils is very healing. The skin is permeable to fat-soluble substances; and relatively impermeable to water-soluble substances. Carrier oils such as Sweet Almond or Grape-seed Oil can be used; as they are less thick and penetrate the skin faster.

  • Inhalation

Another way to get great benefits out of it is by inhalation. Inhalation results in the stimulation of the limbic system of the brain. The nerve impulse in the limbic system leads to other areas of the brain that are responsible for secreting hormones; helping with metabolism and body function.

Three ways a person can inhale essentials oils:

  1. The easiest way it to invest in an aroma diffuser to diffuse the scent.
  2. The old fashion way is to stand head over a bowl of steaming hot water with some drops of essential oils; inhaling the steam, while covering the head with a towel. A routine that is best before bed.
  3. A bottle of the desired essential oil can also be hold close to the nostrils for therapeutic effect.
  • Some are ingested

The last way to use essential oil, is by ingestion. This is not recommended for many oils which are less absorbed through your digestive system. But some can be great for baking/cooking, resulting in the “feel-good effect” in wintertime. I use nutmeg, vanilla, lemon, clove, ginger, and orange or even a little lavender sometimes added to some of my recipes.

Health benefits of essential oils

Essential oils are used by massage therapists, nurses, reflexologists and beauticians, and so on. There are many ways to utilize essentials oils; through steams, vaporizers or sprays. The oils can be put in a bath as well. Due to the numerous health benefits of essential oils, they are increasingly being explored by the scientific community.  They may help alleviate a variety of symptoms associated with cancer, HIV, asthma, bronchitis, strokes, Alopecia, anxiety, hormonal imbalance, depression, insomnia, and pain, among others.

Top 10 must-have oils

I would encourage people to invest in essential oils to support the body’s system.

My emergency kit includes:

  • Oregano oil 

Oregano oil can help alleviate colitis, diarrhea, allergies, bacterial and viral infections, and the common cold.

  • Lavender

Lavender can help relieve headache, insomnia, depression, and nausea.

  • Eucalyptus

It is one of the best essential oils to help fighting sinus problems, congestion, cough, and the common cold.

  • Chamomile

Chamomile can help soothe burns; it can be used for arthritis, menstrual and menopausal symptoms, and digestive problems.

  • Peppermint 

Peppermint essential oil is an excellent remedy for digestive upset, nausea, headache and motion sickness.

  • Tea tree 

Tea tree alleviates the symptoms of common cold, bronchitis, and abscesses and it’s also a powerful antiseptic; it can be used for cleaning purposes as well.

  • Thyme

Thyme helps to relieve gas, intestinal worms, hair Loss such as Alopecia areata.

  • Rosemary

It decreases intestinal gas, fluid retention, and hair loss; and it’s also a good antiseptic.

  • Ginger 

Ginger can help with indigestion, nausea, PMS, inflammation and improve joints conditions.

  • Clove

Clove is a powerful anti-bacterial, anti-parasitic and anti-fungal oil. It can also be used for tooth pain and as a mouthwash.

Which companies are the best out there? And why?

  • The word “Pure” might be of great importance in one company and not in another. There is no regulation about the purity of oils, unfortunately. The term is non-regulated, therefore, people can claim many things.
  • Find out if the oil is adulterated or mixed. The retailer has to have an understanding of essential oils and has to be involved in the essential oil trade to assure quality.
  • Make sure that the company tested the oils.

The essential oil authenticity is that each oil is identified with the plant’s scientific or botanical name. Make sure that your oil is wild-crafted or organic.

Caution:

Many Volatile Oils are toxic when ingested orally; in concentrated amounts higher than those normally ingested through eating the original plant. Although they are often therapeutic when their vapors are inhaled in moderate amounts.

Reference

  • Schulz, V., et al. Rational Phytotherapy, 3rd edition. Springer Verlag, Berlin, Germany. 1998:146-147.
  • Somerville, K., et al. Delayed release peppermint oil capsules (Colpermin) for the spastic colon syndrome: A pharmacokinetic study. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 18:638-640, 1984.

  • Bassett, I. B., et al. A comparative study of tea-tree oil versus benzoylperoxide in the treatment of acne. Medical Journal of Australia. 153:455-458, 1990.
